html:
4.27.18  12:58 am   4.26.18  11:01 pm Are you actually surprised that people associate some of your stuff with depression?

      I mean, you have videos about being 'a piece of garbage' and one titled, 'i hate myself'. There are also recurring themes in your songs about being alone, conflicted, wanting to go home etc. I think it contributes to your popularity, actually - people identify with those themes. 


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201804262301

4.26.18  11:01 pm   Are you aware of the amount of people who feel generally happier after listening to your music?

     me neither

html:
4.26.18  3:04 pm   4.25.18  11:24 pm so what are your thoughts on albums with some kind of narrative structure tied together with skits like Tommy or good kid maad city


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201804252324

4.25.18  11:24 pm   i know you've said before that you like to release your songs one by one. if you were to make an album though, would you be concerned with making the album greater than the sum of its parts

     i would certainly try to put them in the best order, but i think 'greater than the sum of its parts' is a little much to ask of simply a list of songs

      (i.e. thinking about how the songs supplement each other in the context of the album and stuff like that) or would you just continue to write songs as you're used to and maybe arrange them in a way that makes sense but not think of it as "i'm making an album here" but rather "i'm releasing my songs that i would have released anyway as an album here"? would you find the additional creative challenges that come with creating an album exiting?

     if i'm going to make a 45-60 minute project that works well as a whole, i would want to use more than just songs. if it really is just songs then i say let the songs roam free
original_html: 4.26.18  3:04 pm   4.25.18  11:24 pm so what are your thoughts on albums with some kind of narrative structure tied together with skits like Tommy or good kid maad city

answers_original.html:
4.25.18  11:24 pm   i know you've said before that you like to release your songs one by one. if you were to make an album though, would you be concerned with making the album greater than the sum of its parts

     i would certainly try to put them in the best order, but i think 'greater than the sum of its parts' is a little much to ask of simply a list of songs

      (i.e. thinking about how the songs supplement each other in the context of the album and stuff like that) or would you just continue to write songs as you're used to and maybe arrange them in a way that makes sense but not think of it as "i'm making an album here" but rather "i'm releasing my songs that i would have released anyway as an album here"? would you find the additional creative challenges that come with creating an album exiting?

     if i'm going to make a 45-60 minute project that works well as a whole, i would want to use more than just songs. if it really is just songs then i say let the songs roam free

html:
4.19.18  12:03 pm   4.18.18  8:53 am <--- you're the music and i'm the lyrics 


embedded answer: https://billwurtz.com/questions/q.php?date=201804180853

4.18.18  8:53 am   bill how do i write meaningful lyrics?(aka lyrics that sound thought out, and pack a punch) if i write lyrics enough, will i get better at this? should i study other lyrics? help

     the best hint i can give you is that lyrics work best with the music. and the music always seems to work better with the lyrics. the music and lyrics are meant to be together, and i think if they are separated they can suffer separation anxiety and dissociation
original_html: 4.19.18  12:03 pm   4.18.18  8:53 am <--- you're the music and i'm the lyrics

answers_original.html:
4.18.18  8:53 am   bill how do i write meaningful lyrics?(aka lyrics that sound thought out, and pack a punch) if i write lyrics enough, will i get better at this? should i study other lyrics? help

     the best hint i can give you is that lyrics work best with the music. and the music always seems to work better with the lyrics. the music and lyrics are meant to be together, and i think if they are separated they can suffer separation anxiety and dissociation

html:
4.16.18  8:17 pm   4.15.18  10:29 pm well since you asked, i think your longest song on the site (bob marley) is one of your best, because you have lots of time to explore the various directions that the song could go in

and while other artists mostly make short songs, it's not extremely uncommon see a song that is six minutes long, or sometimes even longer. so i found it unusual that you have written a huge number of them but none in the list are five minutes

with that said the length of songs you make is entirely your choice and i respect your creative process, i was just curious if you chose to make shorter songs on account of recording time, feeling like they get repetitive, or something else entirely
